Ryanair calls on airports to ban alcohol before 10am&ldquoI took time off work to drive to the bank but was told by the teller I couldn&rsquot use it.&ldquoI had to go back to the website to try and get them to respond and send a new cheque.&ldquoBut I still haven&rsquot had a reply.Karen Joyce told the BBC she had to wait for 11 months to receive compensation after the flight she had booked for her 25th wedding anniversary was cancelled.&ldquoI have not received anything from Ryanair (Image: )When she did finally receive a cheque the bank returned it unpaid with an added administration fee.She explained: &ldquoI was totally dumbstruck.&ldquoWe were loyal Ryanair customers and for them to bounce the cheque as well I just thought was disgusting.She phoned a Ryanair customer assistant, but noted &ldquohe just put the phone down.She added: &ldquoI have not received anything from Ryanair.Ryanair issued a statement admitting that a &ldquovery small number of cheques were sent out without a signature and said these had been reissued.They blamed this on an &ldquoadministration error and added: &ldquoWe apologise again for any inconvenience caused to customers.Ryanair is currently locked in an industrial dispute with pilots in five countries taking strike action.&ldquoWe apologise again for any inconvenience caused to customers (Image:  )A strike on Friday led to 26 flight cancellations between the UK and Ireland, whilst action on July 25 and 26 resulted in cancellations for 100,000 Ryanair passengers.The Civil Aviation Authority, which oversees civil air travel in the UK, has urged customers to apply for compensation under European air passengers&rsquo rights rules.They could be due &pound357 for cancelled long haul frights, or &pound223 for journeys of less than 1,500km.

title: Brexit news Chuka Umunna Barry Gardiner Labour UK EU withdrawal second referendum latest
story: Chuka Umunna said he was disappointed to hear colleague Barry Gardiner shoot down the possibility of holding a second Brexit referendum on the final withdrawal deal.Mr Gardiner on Tuesday dismissed calls for a fresh vote claiming a re-run would risk a breakdown of law and order, and undermine democracy.Speaking on LBC, the Remainer MP said: It&rsquos hugely disappointing to hear a member of Labour&rsquos shadow cabinet parroting this type of thing you hear from Nigel Farage and Brexiteers.Actually, I&rsquod argue it&rsquos quite irresponsible to be talking in those terms.                Remainers HOWL as Labour Remainer TRASHES calls for second referendum                Corbyn UNABLE to answer simple Brexit question SIX TIMES when grilledLabour politicians have been split so far on whether the party would back a second referendum, with leader&nbspJeremy Corbyn saying in July a new vote is not on the agenda before being rebuffed days later by shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer who claimed Labour&nbspwas not ruling out a new poll.Mr Umunna continued: At the end of the day we are deadlocked in the House of Commons on Brexit, there is not a consensus around how to leave the European Union.&ldquoIn the absence of Parliament being able to come to a decision, I don&rsquot see there being any other alternative but to refer this back to the people.&ldquoIt&rsquos called democracy, which is why I&rsquom very involved with the People&rsquos Vote campaign and democracy did not stop in 2016.Brexit news: Chuka Umunna exploded at Gardiner for parroting Farage (Image: ITV)Mr Gardiner, who backed Remain at the 2016 referendum, insisted the country had to respect the people's vote to leave the European Union to protect British democracy.The shadow International Trade Secretary told the Today programme: Those people who now want a second referendum are saying &lsquobecause you voted in the wrong way, we&rsquoll give you another chance to get it right,' that undermines the whole principle of democracy in this country.What I&rsquom saying in any situation if people feel the root to change is no longer a democratic route then you look to social disruption, perhaps civil disobedience, in a different way and this is playing with our democracy, it&rsquos playing with the foundations of the country in a way that is really damaging.The Labour frontbencher continued: If people want to be able to achieve change through democratic means, if they feel that that is being denied to them, they then turn to other more socially disruptive ways of expressing their views, and that is the danger here.&ldquoWe have to respect people&rsquos vote in that referendum &ndash we told them we would, we must do it.Brexit news: Barry Gardiner said a re-run of the vote would undermine democracy (Image: ITV)The shadow International Trade Minister's intervention was met with criticism from Labour MPs and Remain voters who took to social media to vent their discontent with his statements.Exeter MP Ben Bradshaw, a supporter of the People's Vote campaign, said: I'm afraid Barry Gardiner in defending Brexit whatever the cost on @BBCr4today on democratic grounds completely ignores the democratic right of the people to change their minds.Colleague Chris Leslie said: When Barry Gardiner says giving the public a final say on Brexit would be undemocratic, perhaps he's missed the bit about #PeoplesVote being a democratic voice for the people.We don't stop having general elections if Tories win. We shouldn't deprive public their say on this.But a Deltapoll survey of 1,094 adults published on Sunday revealed that one in four Briton want the Government to deliver Brexit, with only 31 percent backing a new in-out referendum.

title: top uk towns derbyshire raise family research yopa
story: Ashbourne in Derbyshire tops the list for the best town in the UK to raise a family (Image: )Historic Walton on Thames in Surrey &ndash on the river and only 18 miles from the capital - comes in second, while third place goes to Harrogate in North Yorkshire.The northern spa town benefits from little violent crime and lots of green space and is famous for its iconic Betty&rsquos Tearooms.Two Scottish destinations also make the top ten &ndash with Inverness in fourth place and the city of Edinburgh coming in tenth.The top ten have been identified by fixed fee estate agency Yopa, in a bid to help families decide where to move.It has developed on online tool called &lsquomove motivators&rsquo to help the 50 per cent of UK parents it says have considered upping sticks to improve the wellbeing of their children and to secure beter future prospects for them.                Untouched Scottish island has gone on the market for &pound120,000                House sales &lsquoresilient&rsquo with hope for property market in coming weeksDavid Jacobs, co-founder of YopaBased on an algorithm it brings together important data including local schools, crime rate, pollution levels, job prospects, pupils-per-class ratio, and access to well rated GPs.David Jacobs, the co-founder of Yopa, said: &ldquoThere is a good mix of locations in the top ten list and it&rsquos interesting to note their geographical spread across the country.&ldquoWe are committed to helping parents find the very best family home wherever that might be.&ldquoEvery family has a different idea of the best location and our tool enables people to set priorities based on their inidual move motivators.Yopa's study takes into account local schools and the number of pupils per class (Image: )Other factors include the most well-rated GPs (Image: )&ldquoOur research shows that more than half of British parents are willing to relocate for a better quality of life and improved wellbeing for their children.&ldquoWhat&rsquos great to see is that this is not just for the short term either - parents are also driven by their children&rsquos future career prospects and future financial standing.Yopa Happy Home 2018 Top Ten:1. title: bungalow shortage retired pensioners demand uk
story: The ageing population means demand for single storey dwellings is at an all time (Image: )The ageing population means demand for the single storey dwellings is at an all time high, particularly for those worried about mobility up and down stairs as they get older.But a shortage of available land has seen housebuilders concentrate on apartment blocks and flats in the private sector in recent years instead.More than half the nation's over-65s (54 percent) are considering a bungalow as their next and potentially final property move, said housebuilders McCarthy and Stone.That equates to 6.6 million older adults.                Why retirees want super-size bungalows to SAVE money                Retirement bungalows SCANDAL: Pensioners may have to give up on homesHowever, there are an estimated two million bungalows in Britain and only a paltry 2,600 were built last year, said the developer, particularly those aimed on estates specifically geared for retirement living.This is down from 26,000 built in 1986 with both private developers and local authorities concentrating on traditional houses or flats in the past three decades.Council planning departments, under pressure to build more accommodation per square foot are more likely to approve high rise blocks than single storey lone dwellings.Clive Fenton, the Chief Executive of McCarthy &amp Stone, said: There is an urgent need to build more suitable housing to meet the different needs of those in retirement, and bungalows must play a key role.Bungalows have the advantage of easy to maintain outdoor spaces (Image: )Though they were a dying breed, bungalows are making a comeback and are hot property.As the UK rapidly ages, more and more people want to downsize from their large family homes to a bungalow, which is smaller, easier to maintain and offers independent living.In doing so, they free up homes for the UK's younger generation, and also keep older people healthier and happier for longer. It's a win, win for everyone.Apart from step free access, bungalows also have the advantage of easy to maintain outdoor spaces for retirees who prefer to keep a garden rather than be confined to a flat, he added.MPs have recently argued for more bungalows and there are reports that the Government will encourage more to be built to cope with demands of an ageing population.

title: Brexit news UK EU Theresa May Salzburg Austria summit no deal latest
story: The former MEP and European Policy Centre expert said EU leaders should invite the European Commission&rsquos negotiator Michel Barnier to force-feed the UK an extension of the 21-month transition period, which is due to start on March 29 2019 if the withdrawal agreement in concluded.Mr Duff proposes the offer should be made at the informal European Council summit in Salzburg hosted by Austria, the current incumbents of the EU&rsquos rotating presidency, on September 20.He, however, admits the EU should not allow for an extension of Article 50, therefore delaying the UK&rsquos departure, unless there is a constitutional crisis in Britain.Writing in a paper entitled &lsquoBrexit: Beyond the transition&rsquo, Mr Duff said: &ldquoTwo strategic decisions await the summit meeting.                The THREE issues the EU and Britain must resolve                 BREXIT: UK in emergency talks as Barnier says Brexit could be DELAYED &ldquoThe first is to emphasise that there will be no prolongation of the Article 50 process. If Mr Barnier continues to make progress towards the Withdrawal Agreement, an extension of his timetable will in any case be unnecessary.&ldquoTheresa May will not ask for an extension, knowing full well that to do so would break her party. But she needs the summit to puncture the delusion of British Remainers who imagine that the EU 27 are ready to indulge in procrastination.&ldquoThe EU is keen to move on to other matters. Short of a constitutional crisis in Britain, the Union will not postpone Brexit. It would be best to say so at Salzburg.Mr Duff believes both sides of the Channel require a longer transition period in order to deal with the complex future agreement on customs and the Irish border.Brexit news: Theresa May should be 'force-fed' transition extension, says Andrew Duff (Image: )The Prime Minister should be &ldquoforce-fed the concept by her European counterparts if she is too shy to ask for it, he adds.Mr Duff said: &ldquoThe leaders should invite the Commission to include in the withdrawal agreement a provision permitting an extension of the transition period.&ldquoGiven the complexity of the impending negotiation of the association agreement, especially relating to customs and the Irish border, such flexibility is very much in the EU&rsquos interest.&ldquoIf Mrs May is too shy to ask for more time for her &lsquoimplementation period&rsquo, she should be force-fed it.                Brexit news: October deadline DITCHED as UK and EU move to seal deal                'Do not blame the EU!' Barnier lashes out at no-deal Brexit blame game&ldquoBrexiteers will not like it, but business and public administration on both sides of the Channel badly need a longer transition period than that presently agreed.Time has been made on the Salzburg schedule for Mrs May to hold a Brexit discussion with her fellow 27 EU leaders, which goes against normal protocol.Mr Duff believes a successful Salzburg summit can be the driving force by the UK and EU being able to complete the withdrawal agreement, even before the October summit in Brussels.&ldquoIf Salzburg is a success, rapid progress can be made to complete the Withdrawal Agreement at the October European Council, he said.Michel Barnier believes October is too soon to sign Brexit withdrawal agreement (Image: )On Tuesday, Mr Barnier cast doubt on the Brexit timeline when he said he wasn&rsquot sure if they can conclude departure negotiations ahead of the perceived October deadline.He said: &ldquoWhen deciding what is realistic and not realistic, you have to take the date that Theresa May chose for the departure of the United Kingdom from the European Union &ndash March 30, I think it's actually enshrined in law in the UK now.If you count backwards from that date, March 30 2019, the day on which the UK will no longer be a member of the European Union &ndash while remaining for 21 months, if we reach an agreement, in the single market, customs union and European policies &nbsp&ndash the countdown backwards from there has to take account of the time which is necessary for ratification.&nbspThat is a given, it will take a certain amount of time to ratify the agreement &ndash on the UK side and the European side.&nbspThat takes us for a final agreement on the withdrawal agreement and political declaration well before the end of the year &ndash I'm not going to say October, a few days here, the beginning of November, but not much later than that.

title: Brexit news SNP Mike Russell UK EU withdrawal Scotland Nicola Sturgeon latest
story: SNP Brexit minister Mike Russell suggested the British Government has lost the mandate to deliver Brexit with its plans to seek a hard exit from the European Union.The SNP has long adopted an anti-Brexit position, with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon denouncing on Tuesday the economic risks of leaving the bloc.Speaking at a public event in Dunoon on August 20, Mr Russell said: There is, however, there was a mandate on the UK level for what is taking place, no longer a mandate.Whatever that mandate was for it was not explicitly for the hardest and most damaging form of Brexit, which is what we appear to be heading towards.                Theresa May's relationship with Nicola Sturgeon hits &lsquoROCK BOTTOM&rsquoMr Russell claimed the Brexit process had deteriorated substantially and the Government should reconsider its deadlines to make sure the UK is protected from any damaging consequences of leaving the EU.He continued: In a logical political system you would think that somebody would say &lsquohold on, this has changed, things have changed. Let&rsquos just slow down and work out what we actually want to do now.&rsquoBut, in fact, the situation has deteriorated substantially in the last two to three months and now the trajectory is towards that hard and very damaging Brexit which could be a no deal outcome.The SNP frontbencher also took a dig at both the Tories and Labour over their isiveness and detachment from their support base.&nbspBrexit news: Mike Russell claimed Mrs May has no mandate to deliver Brexit (Image: &bullYOUTUBEDemocracyLiveScot)He added: When the history of this is written it will take an awful lot to understand how that position could have been countered.It&rsquos not just a Tory party that&rsquos desperate not to fall apart and desperate to stay in Government but it&rsquos also a Labour party that has not taken the opposition ground people thought it would take.Presenting figures on Scotland's budget deficit, Mrs Sturgeon said on August 21 that Brexit is a real and present danger to the Scottish and UK economy, reinforcing once more her anti-Brexit position.She added: The debate for Scotland over the period ahead is how do we best equip ourselves to support the best possible economic performance.

title: UK wasps hot weather insects heatwave
story: Britain faces a huge growth in wasps due to the heatwave (Image: )This was demonstrated though figures released today - by Rentokil Pest Control - which&nbspsaw a&nbsp369 per cent rise in wasp-related enquiries&nbspin July this year, compared to the same period in 2017.&nbspDavid Cross, Rentokil's head of the technical training academy, said:&nbsp&ldquoThe hotter weather has caused wasps to venture out more, which lowers the mortality rate inside the nest, meaning more people will come into contact with them.&nbspIn cooler summers, wasps stay inside their homes and generate more moisture, leading to an increased risk of fungal infections in the insects that cause some to die of natural causes.&nbspMr Cross advised householders to be careful with how they dispose litter, particularly food waste.                Alarm at stinging frenzy by swarms of lager lout wasps                Toddler twins suffer horror stings as wasps invade areaHe said: &ldquoIt is important that consumers take care of their rubbish properly.&nbspIdeally, food and drink waste should be disposed of in a sealed bag or container to help prevent attracting insects such as wasps, flies, ants as well as other pests like rodents and birds too.&nbsp&ldquoWhere possible, food and drink should also be stored in sealed containers to avoid attracting insects.But the increase in wasps is good news for gardeners, as they are a useful partner against plant-eating insects such as moth caterpillars which they feed off.Wasps become more of a nuisance to humans in late summer, when the queen stops producing eggs&nbsp and most larvae has grown into adults.The British Pest Control Association (BPCA) has also seen seen an increase in call-outs over wasps.&nbspKevin Higgins, BPCA technical advisor, said the &ldquowarm spell has had an impact and numbers have been rising significantly.He said: &ldquoAn early abundance of fruit in the fields and gardens gives better feeding conditions in which they can thrive.                Wasps: How to get rid of wasps in your home with a &pound2.40 oil                Summer wasp WARNING: Pest controllers on HIGH ALERT for boozed insectsAnt numbers increased dramatically in spring 2018 (Image: )With an average temperature of 17.2C (62.9F), last month was the third hottest July recorded in the UK, behind 2006 and 1983. Faversham in Kent saw the highest UK July temperature this year, when the barometer reached a sweltering 35.3C (95.5F).Rentokil said the hot weather had also resulted in more fly-related enquiries - which were up 20 per cent this July, compared to 2017.Mr Cross said: &ldquoThe lifecycle of a fly is sped up in warmer weather.&nbsp&ldquoHouse flies will lay between 500 and 900 eggs usually in batches of 100 to 150.&nbsp&ldquoDevelopment from egg to adult can take as little as seven days in 30C heat and when they reach adulthood they will breed almost immediately.There was also an increase in ants, with call-outs to Rentokil increasing by 148 per cent from March to April due to the unusually mild spring.

title: uk weather forecast latest met office long range bbc weather el nino
story: While the effects of El Nino in Europe are under debate, experts warn it could trigger another cold British winter this year.The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) said there is a 70 per cent chance of an event becoming established over the next four months.It would be the sixth to strike in the past 15 years with previous events happening in 200203 200405, 200607, 200910 and 201415.El Nino - which is linked to extreme weather events across the globe - is triggered by a weakening of the easterly trade winds over the Pacific.                UK weather forecast: Britain braced for RAIN and MURKY CLOUD                 BBC weather forecast: August Bank Holiday set to be a WASHOUT                 Hawaii Hurricane Lane warning: Category 3 storm could hit Hawaii                When will Typhoon Soulik hit Japan? When will Cimaron hit Japan?&ldquoThey are associated with widespread changes in the climate system that last several months, and can lead to significant human impacts affecting things such as infrastructure, agriculture, health and energy sectors.Climate scientists say it is too early to determine what effect if any another El Nino will have on global weather patterns.Mat Collins, professor of climate science at the University of Exeter, said: &ldquoThe issue will be the size of the El Nino event.&ldquoWeak events happen quite frequently , there has been a lot of variability between 1997 and 2016.&ldquoIt could turn out to be a strong event or it could be quite weak, it will be a case of keeping an eye on developments in the Pacific.&ldquoEl Nino can have greater impacts on places like Indonesia and India where it can affect the monsoon.&ldquoThis can affect crops and this has a knock-on effect in the UK when it comes to importing goods such as coffee.Katie Greening, a meteorologist with The Weather Company, said this El Nino is slightly different from other events with rising sea temperatures concentrates towards the middle of the Pacific.While there is much speculation over the relationship between El Nino and the British weather it could lead to lower than normal winter temperatures, she added.She said: &ldquoFor a classic El Nino pattern, unusually warm waters build over the eastern tropical Pacific, near the coast of South America.Parts of the Continent can also become prone to higher rainfall  (Image: )Wednesday weather map  (Image: WXCHARTS)&ldquoThe last two classic El Nino events have been associated with very mild winters across Europe.&ldquoAs we move into Autumn and winter 2018, however, models suggest the upcoming El Nino may take on a so-called &lsquoModoki&rsquo look.&ldquoModoki is Japanese for &lsquosimilar but different&rsquo and in this case warm sea surface temperatures pool in the central tropical Pacific.&ldquoThere is very limited research and material on Modoki style El Nino.&ldquoHowever, it's very early days but there are suggesting it may lead towards a cool lean during the winter months across Europe.

title: Typhoon Soulik update typhoon Cimaron path track graph latest Japan Korean Peninsula
story: Typhoon Soulik began to unleash heavy showers and powerful gales on Japan on Wednesday, with forecasters warning the typhoon is expected to continue affecting southern areas until the early hours of Thursday before moving on towards the Korean Peninsula.A shocking graph from NIWA Weather shows Typhoon Cimaron will follow in the footsteps of Soulik within hours to threaten mainland Japan with flooding rainfall and damaging winds.The graphic shows the twin typhoons will follow a similar path over Japan but Soulik will then target the Korean Peninsula while Cimaron is set to head for the Sea of Japan.AccuWeather's senior meteorologist Adam Douty said: While Soulik bypassed mainland Japan to the south, strengthening Typhoon Cimaron is expected to make landfall in southern mainland Japan during the second half of the week.                Typhoon Soulik latest: TERRIFYING video of storm on track to hit Japan                Typhoon Cimaron path update: Where is it and when will it hit Japan?Current indications are that Cimaron will target southern Japan on Thursday. Kyushu, Shikoku and southern Honshu will be at the greatest risk.A track over Shikoku and western Honshu is forecast on Thursday and Thursday night prior to the storm entering the Sea of Japan on Friday.Cimaron was last tracked about 659 km north-northeast of Guam on Tuesday evening, holding steady at 75 mph sustained winds and 92 mph gusts.Residents of Kyushu, Shikoku and western Honshu have been warned to pay attention to local officials and follow possible evacuation orders that might be ordered as the tropical cyclone approaches.Typhoon Cimaron is not expected to be as strong as Typhoon Soulik but it can bring wind damage and flooding to previously hard-hit areas.Typhoon Soulik update: Typhoon Cimaron will follow Soulik making landfall in Japan (Image: TWITTERNiwaWeather)After the cyclone has passed heavy rain in the northern part of Japan is expected as the weekend approaches.Tropical cyclones are common throughout the summer months in Japan, especially in August and September.The 2018 Pacific typhoon season is an ongoing event in which tropical cyclones form in the western Pacific Ocean.Natural disasters are a well-known phenomena in Japan with large earthquakes and tropical storms.Most cyclones in the area develop between May and October, but the 2018 cyclone season is said to run until the end of the year.

title: EU news European Union Poland Slovakia Romania Czech Republic Slovenia
story: The EU's stability could be shattered this autumn, experts said (Image: )Political uncertainty across the region threatens to plunge the bloc into a major crisis, the US-based Freedom House think-tank said.Zselyke Csaky, a researcher at Freedom House, raised fears about turmoil in Poland, Slovakia, Romania, the Czech Republic and Slovenia.She told Politico: The autumn months will be about governments being put to the test in the region.Local elections are coming both in Poland and Slovakia.                Labour Brexit clash: Umunna EXPLODES at Gardiner 'PARROTING Farage'                BREXIT: UK in emergency talks as Barnier says Brexit could be DELAYED Romania's battered government will have to survive without getting a new prime minister, again.And the minority coalitions in both the Czech Republic and Slovenia will have to show they actually work.The only government that will safely flex its muscles is in Hungary.It will indeed do so by embarking on an already announced kulturkampf, a culture struggle, against its latest 'enemies.'Political uncertainty threatens to plunge the bloc into crisis (Image: EXPRESS)PolandWarsaw's right-wing government is locked in a fierce dispute over the rule of law.The ruling Law and Justice party has passed a series of controversial laws aimed at bringing the judiciary under political control.Brussels threatened to remove Poland's EU voting rights as it attacked the clear risk of a serious breach of the rule of law.The European Commission also warned it could cut financing for member states flouting democratic standards.However, Poland claims the judicial reforms are needed to improve the efficiency of its courts. journalist Jan Kuciak and his wife.Mr Fico's resignation handed the country's three-party ruling coalition to Peter Pellegrini.However, activists say Mr Pellegrini has not done enough to crack down on d'etat.Czech president Andrej Babis faces a police probe into alleged fraud (Image: )Czech Republic and SloveniaThe Czech Republic and Slovenia also pose a threat to the EU's stability.Czech president party to be able to rule.And Slovenia's newly appointed prime minister Marjan Sarec is currently trying to form a coalition.No party won an overall majority in the country's general election in June, title: venezuela news currency latest nicolas maduro sovereign bolivar
story: President Nicol&aacutes Maduro revealed the new banknotes earlier in the week, revaluing and renaming the old currency.The money went into circulation on Tuesday, with the government claiming that it will curb hyperinflation. However, critics believe it could worsen the situation. Thousands of businesses closed in preparation for the new currency - the sovereign bolivar - leading to many people not going to work and bringing the country to a temporary halt.However, Mr Maduro praised the new currency on Twitter:The head of state praised the move on Twitter (Image: )We found the revolutionary formula that puts work in the centre of the general re-adjustment of society, based on the production of goods and the value of salary. With that, we're gonna put to rest forever the perverse model that dollarised the prices in the country.Later in the day he added: I call on the people to defend - conscientiously - the adjustment of the prices on street.The new currency has five fewer zeroes than its predecessor and will be pegged to Venezuela&rsquos cryptocurrency, the petro, which was banned in March by President Donald Trump, who claimed it was launched to skirt US sanctions.US citizens cannot trade in the currency and cryptocurrency site, ICOindex, has even labelled the petro &ldquoa scam. title: California earthquake today map where California earthquake
story: The earthquake struck in the early hours of the morning in California (Image: USGS)Oregan was hit by a magnitude 6.3 earthquake off the north-west coast, shaking buildings.Hitting California at 2.31am local time (10.31am BST) the quake struck&nbspat a depth of about 10 km, according to the United States Geological Survey (USGS).The tremor was recorded around 200 kilometres off the coast of the California-Oregon State border.Officials have said there was no damage to buildings, and that no tsunami warning has been issued for now.According to maps issued by the USGS, shaking was felt in the north-west of California, close to the border with Oregan.&nbspThe quake struck along the&nbspBlanco Fracture Zone&nbspor&nbspBlanco Transform Fault Zone (BTFZ).The fault zone runs northeast off the coast of&nbspOregon&nbspin the&nbspPacific Northwest&nbspof the&nbspUnited States, and reaches from the Gorda Ridge&nbspin the south to the&nbspJuan de Fuca Ridge&nbspin the north.Officials had warned of an impending earthquake, following increased activity along the Ring of Fire.&nbspA total of 16 significant tremors which measured above magnitude 4.5 were registered along the Ring of Fire on Monday.They shook Indonesia, Bolivia, Japan and Fiji but didn't hit the western coast of the US, which lies on the Ring of Fire fault line.The Ring of Fire is a horseshoe shaped&nbspstring of&nbsp452 volcanoes with high seismic activity in the Pacific Ocean.&nbspLarge earthquakes along the deadly ring of fire have devastated the islands of Lombok and Bali in recent days.&nbsp                Carr fire 2018 map: What is the containment of the Carr fire?                Earthquake WARNING: Ring of Fire unrest could lead to BIG ONEMore than 300 people died in the earthquakes that hit the Indonesian islands, with nearly a million residents displaced.&nbspRoughly 90 percent of the world's earthquakes take place along the Ring of Fire.It covers a massive area from New Zealand to Chile, as well as encompassing the Asian and the American coasts.Scientists have warned that recent unrest along the ring of fire could lead to a devastating earthquake soon.&nbspThe earthquake struck 200km off the western coast of the US (Image: USGS)The deadly ring of fire has seen an increase in activity of late (Image: USGS)Fears centre around a&nbsp'Big One'&nbspwhich could soon hit California.&nbspRichard Aster, Professor of Geophysics at Colorado State University, recently said: The earthquake situation in California is actually more dire than people who aren't seismologists like myself may realise.&ldquoAlthough many Californians can recount experiencing an earthquake, most have never personally experienced a strong one.For major events, with magnitudes of seven or greater, California is actually in an earthquake drought.

story: The French premier taunted his critics before he left for holiday (Image: )The French premier taunted his critics before he left for holiday.It came after it was revealed he did not fire his bodyguard, Alexandre Benalla, when the aide was caught on camera manhandling protesters at a Paris rally.But a month later, no one has come after Macron and according to expert in constitutional law from the Universit&eacute de Versailles Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines, Olivier Pluen, no one will.Mr Pluen thinks Macron&rsquos remarks are posturing because the French constitution stops presidents from being interrogated or prosecuted in office to preserve the presidential office and the role of head of state it entails. which we aren&rsquot trying to contest &ndash protects him precisely from any obligation to be accountable.Macron faced a crisis after a video of his security chief assaulting protesters was revealed (Image: )                No Deal is 'SO RADICAL' Britain will NOT do it: France mocks UK                 France issues bridge warning with 840 structures at risk of COLLAPSE Mr Macron faced the biggest political crisis of his tenure after a video of his security chief beating up two protesters was revealed by the daily Le Monde.The video sparked nationwide outrage, with opposition leaders accusing the government of failing to properly punish Mr Benalla or refer him promptly to judicial authorities.Macron also criticised the French media&rsquos coverage of the incident, saying: &ldquoWe have a press that is no longer pursuing the truth&hellip What I see is media power that wants to become judicial power.The incident caused a dramatic tumble in his popularity as a result.Marine Le Pen said Mr Macron&rsquos remarks were 'not very fair play' (Image: )A poll conducted by YouGov earlier this month for the Huffington Post and the French television channel CNews, showed that Mr Macron&rsquos approval rating had fallen to 27 percent, down five percentage points from June.The survey also marked the young centrist&rsquos lowest YouGov approval rating since he took power in May 2017.At 62 per cent, Mr Macron&rsquos disapproval rating reached a record high, YouGov said, although the polling institute stressed that respondents had been asked to comment on &ldquothe president&rsquos actions, and not on his image.

title: Hurricane Lane Hawaii news now update latest news category 5
story: KHNON2 reporters warned viewers that hurricane experts had flown into the storm yesterday evening (6.30 HST) in order to determine the strength of the hurricane. They then placed the hurricane in category 5, the highest category a hurricane can be given.Forecaster Justin Cruz told viewers of KHON2 News: &ldquoHurricane Lane has strengthened just a notch from 150mph winds from around the centre of the system, which put it on a category 4. Now it&rsquos up to 160 mph per hour, which put it at a category 5.&ldquoThe system sits around 500 miles South East of the Big Island. Overall it is a very healthy system with a clearly defined eye.&ldquoThere&rsquos very low wind shear right now, and also warm waters to keep it healthy.                How should you prepare for Hurricane Lane?Wind shear is still expected to weaken Hurricane Lane as it approaches the state, but at the current moment, the hurricane is still at the height of its strength.Mr Cruz told viewers: &ldquoThere is a weakening trend. We expect it to kick in soon, but it has not kicked in yet.The hurricane's current trajectory will take Hurricane Lane very close to the Big Island on Wednesday, with the expectation that it will have weakened to a category 3 hurricane.In an urgent alert, Hawaii's County Civil Defence Agency told residents to prepare for 149mph gales and heavy rains which could cause severe damage and flooding.Hurricane Lane: The hurricane lane has been given a category 5 upgrade overnight. title: young women getting 99 botox
story: After all, in the era of Love Island and social media, we’re all potential celebrities now. Even those of us who will never hit the big time have an Instagram audience waiting to “like” our every selfie.So this is just the logical next step towards making cosmetic surgery available to the masses, rather than the few.Some have argued that Superdrug Botox is actually a good thing, because it bridges the gap between the elite Harley Street options — where you pay several hundred pounds for an appointment with an “aesthetic doctor” — and the more backstreet treatments carried out by hairdressers with just a few hours of training.I disagree. Being able to buy a syringe or two of Botox when you are out shopping for your hairspray legitimises — and normalises — the act of injecting poison in your skin in the name of beauty.Being able to buy Botox over the counter, so to speak, makes it seem like no big deal — just another tick in the “maintenance” box, and as reasonable as tinting your lashes or getting your ears pierced.And that is the problem. All decisions we make about our appearance boil down to personal choice. And if it makes someone feel better to tinker cosmetically or surgically with their natural looks, that’s their choice. No one should judge them for it.But there is a wider problem.Increasingly, women think that whatever they look like naturally isn’t good enough. More and more, the “solution” is invasive cosmetic enhancement.A mainstream shop making Botox available for less than 100 quid is surely only going to add to the pressure some women feel to change their appearance using more than just make-up.Superdrug presents itself as responsible because it will refuse to treat under-25s, when other clinics will.That is shocking — not so much that some clinics WILL treat under-25s but that anyone so young could think they need Botox.You can’t blame Superdrug for this epidemic. It is simple supply and demand.The question is: Why the growing desire among women to look frozen?It’s not like you can get away with saying you’ve not had it when you have, because it’s so obvious.I’ve got a friend whose husband jokes that she needs to hold up little signs saying “happy” or “angry” when she feels an emotion, since her face is so paralysed by botulism.While I’m a big believer in your body, your choice, I’m also a believer in scratching the right itch.The truth is if you feel good about yourself, you look good. If you feel bad and lack confidence, nothing, no amount of Botox or fillers, will ever change that.Just look at Meg from Love Island, above, who, even after an estimated £40,000 worth of plastic surgery, is still massively insecure.Because it’s not what’s on the outside that counts, it’s what’s on the inside.The problem is our society tends to give far too much weight to the outside. That is especially the case for women, but increasingly for men, too.I realise all of this is easy to say, harder to act on. I’m as susceptible as the next person to comparing myself with ­others more beautiful — and possibly more airbrushed — and finding myself lacking.I’m just glad that, when that happens, I know the thing that will make me feel better is far more likely to be self-acceptance than Botox.After all, if you tighten a prune you don’t get a grape — you just get a tight prune!So the really big question is, how to achieve self-acceptance when we are surrounded by all these images of perfection?Well, we are all on our own journey with that one but I’ve got some suggestions which might help.The first is to focus on what you have, rather than what you don’t. And the second is to never, ever compare yourself to anyone else.Forget Botox, you can have that advice for free.You’re welcome.We all enjoyed cheering on the Three Lions players that would quickly become our heroes during the World Cup in Russia this summer.Sadly, those heady days are over and we were reminded of the seamier side of sport this week with the arrest of England rugby union ace Danny Cipriani.His embarrassing brawl outside a Jersey nightclub came hot on the heels of England cricket’s Ben Stokes’ trial over his clash with two men during a night out.Stokes was cleared, but what links these sorry sagas is our drinking culture, which dictates that consuming excessive amounts of alcohol is a normal way of letting off steam.Sportsmen are supposed to be role models, as they influence young people and need to keep themselves in good physical shape.But as long as we think it is OK to binge and push our bodies to the limits rather than sip a few drinks, then violence, injuries and stupid mistakes will continue to be a regular feature of our nights out.And if you are an England sports star, then public shame is just one of the tragic consequences – along with the end of your career – that you might have to face.Why should anyone be surprised at the news that sexual harassment in the police force is rife?Let’s face it, it happens everywhere. So why should the police be any exception?I thought they might hold themselves to higher standards. But no.A new survey reveals that dirty jokes, inappropriate touching, leering and being pressured to have sex are daily issues for many police staff.In a survey of almost 1,800 police staff in England, Wales and Scotland, half had heard sexualised jokes and one in five had received a sexually explicit email or text from a colleague.Shockingly, one in five had also been touched in a way that made them feel uncomfortable.Our head of police at West Ham is a woman.She is smart, tough, brave and would never put up with this type of behaviour.Part of the problem is that many women accept these actions as “normal” and don’t even know how to object. We must learn to stop putting up with it.But it is much more important that men learn what is OK and what is not.End of.Jacinda Ardern – the Prime Minister of New Zealand, who has continued to work since becoming a mother in June – was criticised this week for “using her baby as a prop” after she was seen breastfeeding her daughter at a public meeting.I guess whoever coined that phrase has never had the experience of looking after a baby who needs to be fed – right NOW.Nor will they have dealt with the very loud consequences of that failing to happen.Instead, what about congratulating Jacinda on doing such a great job of being a working mum?We said farewell to two legends last week, let’s remember them with this wonderful meme....So interesting that the day after A-level results arrived, more than 26,000 university places were still available.An Ipsos Mori poll found that while most students still think university is “important”, that is down from 86 per cent five years ago to 75 per cent now.Since a degree is expensive – and no guarantee of a job – you can see why people are questioning the validity of one.However, there is no viable alternative.There are just 10,000 degree-level apprenticeships available, compared with 300,000 university places, according to Sir Peter Lampl, of the Sutton Trust.We need to think how we prepare young people for work and we need more technical qualifications at degree level that offer the chance of a bright future.GOT a story? title: remoaners dream second referendum codswallop
story: Today, a Sun on Sunday poll shows that idea to be total codswallop.Voters simply want our politicians to get on with delivering Brexit.The majority of people have not changed their mind since the referendum. Our poll shows those that have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave. Project Fear has never worked, and it is not going to suddenly start working now. The public are wise to it.Our poll makes it clear that fudging Brexit would unleash serious anger among the electorate. The Government should take notice.Almost half of voters already reckon that the political classes in Britain are making heavy weather of Brexit, in the vain and misguided belief that they can get the public to change their mind.Meanwhile, the drop in support for Theresa May in the polls and Ukip’s rise is a further indication of what the public thought of her Chequers proposals.Millions more will abandon the Tories if Brexit ends up being fudged.Remoaners and Brussels have done their best since the Leave vote to make us think we made a terrible mistake and that the cards are stacked in the EU’s favour.Well, today’s poll is clear. title: theresa may tory leadership contest trevor kavanagh opinion
story: While Theresa May tours the capitals of Europe looking for peace on Brexit, war has broken out between diehard Remainers and fervent Brexiteers.Ex-Ukip leader Nigel Farage has stormed back into the fray with Vote Leave II, a remake of his 2016 referendum triumph.In the pro-Brussels corner, Superdry fashion tycoon Julian Dunkerton is forking out £1million for what must surely be a futile, last-ditch bid to keep Britain in the EU.And just to make things extra interesting for the party conference season, the stampede for Mrs May’s Tory crown is already unstoppable.Indeed, the question is no longer if, or even when, the contest takes place. It is whether the PM herself will seize the initiative and signal her own plan to jump before she is pushed.The undeclared contest has transformed Britain’s negotiating stance — from Theresa May’s meek, slow-motion surrender to a strident demand for a decent, honourable settlement. The good news is that while MPs have been away on holiday, Brussels has begun to blink.At long last it has dawned on our EU neighbours that they have more to lose from a messy Brexit than we do.Forfeiting the UK’s £40billion ransom payment — plus our annual £12billion contribution — would instantly cripple the EU expansionary budget plans and plunge poorer nations such as Greece into crisis.Car and pharmaceutical giants, not to mention French farmers, who export vast stocks to the UK, would be plunged into crisis. Cooperation on crime, security and defence would be at risk. Governments across Europe are now piling pressure on Brussels to see sense.Tory leadership wannabes have sniffed the way the wind is blowing.The Tories won’t pick another Remainer as party leader. Nor does this Government have a prayer at the next election unless it can see off Nigel Farage and his Ukip insurgents with a deal that satisfies the 52 per cent who voted Leave.This explains a sudden enthusiasm at the top for stating the blindingly obvious: Britain will survive a clean Brexit, while an obstructive Brussels will be diminished.After two years of being bossed around by EU bully Michel Barnier, senior Cabinet ministers are coming out as born-again Eurosceptics. Foreign Secretary and repentant Remainer Jeremy Hunt admits Britain will experience some turbulence, but says the EU will be damaged “for a generation”.His warning is echoed by Brexit supremo Dominic Raab, who has rubbished “Project Fear” stories about food and medicine shortages.While loyally insisting a deal is “still the most likely outcome”, Mr Raab insists Britain will cope with the alternative.Hunt and Raab are now openly jockeying for the top job — along with Home Secretary Sajid Javid, Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson, Treasury chief Liz Truss and a host of others.Significantly, Michael Gove seems out of the race after endorsing Mrs May’s Chequers sellout. So where does this leave Boris Johnson? If tens of thousands of grass- roots Tory supporters have anything to do with it, he would be way out in front. As things stand, they don’t.BoJo is out of office and fighting confected outrage over Muslim face masks. Enemies such as the priestly Dominic Grieve threaten to quit the party if he is elected.Under present rules, Boris needs enough support from fellow MPs to be one of the two candidates submitted to party members for a final verdict. His rivals will do anything to stop him — which is why party activists are demanding rule changes to allow any MP with 20 votes to enter the final ballot.Boris has gone quiet — but not for long. He is reportedly planning a nationwide tour — complete with bright-red battle bus — trashing Mrs May’s Chequers deal and calling for a clean Brexit.There will be plenty of opportunities for car-crash interviews and zipwire-style TV images. But the bookies aren’t the only ones making BoJo the clear favourite as Britain’s next Prime Minister.He names Somalis, Ethiopians, North and Central Africans and Afghans as being responsible for the knife-gang slaughter of young black and Asian men.“Race is part of the picture,” says the equality campaigner. “Failing to point this out impedes the fight against these crimes and imperils yet more children of colour.”He is right, isn’t he?But how long before this decent black man is himself accused of racism for daring to tell this unvarnished truth?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa mays electoral prospects depend on how she deals with mass uncontrolled immigration post brexit
story: As usual, she’ll be more focused on the advice of civil servants than her own colleagues or the guidance from her Chief Whip or the wider Cabinet.She would be unwise to ignore the evidence from polls and her own MPs, that the settled opinion of the country is simply “thus far and no further” and that instead the best way to get back onto the front foot is to work up more concessions to the EU and specifically, surrendering the last major red line: On mass uncontrolled immigration via free movement.We can see clues of further surrender in the fuzzy language from the Chequers agreement: The Government is commitment to “allowing citizens to travel freely without a visa, for tourism and temporary business activity…” But what will “temporary” really mean? Will our current free movement regime be rebadged as a “Labour Mobility Framework”?Such a move, speculated on in the media this week, would be politically toxic and very poorly timed. It would also betray her own instincts, which she rightly gave voice to when she became Prime Minister.Striking a chord with millions of people angry and alienated at their voices being ignored by the political elite on immigration and the downside of globalisation, delivered for her record poll ratings then and a real feeling of hope that at last people in power were listening.Yes, the main driver for the Leave vote was about democracy, independence and national sovereignty but it was also about the fundamental choice that a UK outside the EU would have: Who comes to our country and on what basis – decided by our own Parliament.Voters have noticed that the tightening of the labour market and record employment levels, as revealed by the Office for National Statistics last week, mean that at long last real wages – i.e. pay packets less inflation – are slowly rising and that belatedly big business is beginning to move away from an over reliance on cheap foreign labour, undercutting the pay and conditions of indigenous workers and giving rise to higher welfare dependency.It might seem a radical concept, but such employers might just have to pay workers decent wages, train them better, improve their skills and try hard to retain them. That’s why EU workers are still coming to the UK in huge numbers, despite ridiculous Project Fear stories to the contrary.So yes – Brexit will mean higher pay for British workers! Top businessman Stuart Rose, briefly spokesman for the Remain campaign, accurately predicted such a development before the EU Referendum.Regrettably, the multinationals’ trades union, the CBI didn’t get the message: No surprise that they now want no restrictions on foreign workers post Brexit – in other words an endless pool of cheap labour just like now.Likewise, they’re happy to defend the growing gap between average pay and that of FTSE 100 bosses.Ironically, The Prime Minister could still snatch victory from defeat on this issue, notwithstanding her lamentable record as Home Secretary on reducing net immigration to the tens of thousands.The alternative White Paper which David Davis and his Ministers were working on prior to it being dumped at Chequers, was much more evidence-based and looked to many workable international examples of mobility agreements between first world countries like Australia, the United States, Japan and Canada, as a model for future EU-UK immigration arrangements, to our mutual benefit.The policy would have been informed by the Migration Advisory Committee which reports next month, focused on what was the sensible policy for the whole of the UK and all business sectors rather than a noisy minority and their well-paid advocates.It also sought to end the systemic bias towards low paid and low skilled EU citizens over the well qualified from across the globe.It was pro controlled immigration and not about pulling up the drawbridge and that’s where most British voters are now.Will Theresa May use the opportunity to keep faith with the millions of people in the north and the midlands, in south Wales and south west, who look to her to keep her promises and defend their interests and not just those of the well heeled, the multinationals and those comfortable with the Brussels status quo?Will putative leadership contender Sajid Javid have the courage to resist further attempts at craven supplication on continuing free movement in all but name? Will Conservative MPs who benefited from the highest ever blue collar vote for their party in history, ignore their own electors’ concerns and just accept further concessions?The electoral prospects of her party depend on it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu congratulates themselves for saving greece
story: Look at Greece now as it finally emerges from eight years of monstrous bailouts it will be paying back for decades.Savage cuts and tax rises have slashed its GDP by a quarter. A third of its ten million population are in poverty. One in five cannot afford electricity or rent.Forty per cent of young people are jobless. Many in work earn half what they did ten years ago.Hundreds of thousands of Greece’s brightest have fled.The Eurozone works nicely for Germany . . . but that’s it. Thank God we never signed up to it.Brexit Anxiety Disorder is real, two top psychologists believe. It certainly explains the gibbering hallucinations of Andrew Adonis and his mates.Two grievous losses tipped this complacent Remoaner elite over the edge:The control over our national direction to which they always felt entitled. And our departure from the corrupt, bullying, protectionist EU club they bizarrely consider a beacon of liberal values.Their latest co-ordinated ruse — backed by rich celebrities, has-been politicians and former newspapers — is to pretend a second referendum would “bring a divided Britain together”.They are actually arguing that after two years of abusing 17.4million Leavers as thick racists, Remainers now deserve a second chance to get what they wanted. And that, whatever the result, we would all magically unite behind it.If there’s a more laughably mad contention, we haven’t heard it.We might once have wondered what they were smoking. But the truth is simpler: they are just genuinely barking.It has known for a year the prison was dangerously understaffed. What were the MoJ officials onsite up to?The stories now emerging are appalling. Constant violence. Lags living in terror, warders more so. A “secure” staff car park torched. Routine use of drugs and synthetic highs, brazenly dropped by drones flown in by crime gangs.It’s not about whether prisons are run by the private or public sector. Too many of both are in a parlous state. Cuts have bitten too deeply — and the Government has just hoped for the best.It cannot go on. These jails shame modern Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: stop being a jerk over jamie olivers recipes dawn butler sharing cultures enriches our world
story: Not because she had a bad spag bol in one of his restaurants.Not because he is crusading for a sugar tax that would hike up the price of some delicious drinks and treats.Not even because he once branded parents who occasionally give their kids junk food “tossers”.No, she is mad at him because he has committed the crime of “cultural appropriation”.In a bizarre Twitter rant, Butler, the MP for Brent Central, raged against Oliver’s latest supermarket product Punchy Jerk Rice.In her view, it is an act of cultural theft for a white British chef to make a ­Jamaican dish — or a botched version of a Jamaican dish, as she sees it.“I’m just wondering do you know what Jamaican jerk actually is?”, she asked the celeb chef. “Your jerk rice is not OK.”How weird for an MP to issue papal-style decrees on what chefs may and may not cook up in the kitchen.And then came her killer point: “This appropriation from Jamaica needs to stop.”There it is, the A-word. Appropriation.In the eyes of today’s politically correct policers of “wrongthink”, there is no greater crime than cultural appropriation.Cultural appropriation is when people embrace the grub or music or ideas of a culture that isn’t theirs.Like when Kylie Jenner wore her hair in cornrows. Or when Katy Perry donned a Japanese kimono. Or when drunken lads on a university campus put on sombreros as they neck shots of tequila.All of these things have been branded cultural appropriation by today’s potty warriors against “offensiveness”.And to this blacklist of things we must never appropriate, we can now add non-native foods.This is not the first time Jamie Oliver has been criticised for making foreign dishes. Two years ago foodies were up in arms when he put chorizo in paella — which the Spanish tend not to do.Clearly Jamie Oliver is only allowed to cook “white” British food, like roast beef and toad-in-the-hole.Not Cornish pasties or Yorkshire puddings, though.After all, what right does a man born in Essex have to appropriate the food of Northerners and people from the West Country? And presumably Dawn Butler only ever tucks into Jamaican dishes.If it is cultural appropriation for Oliver to make jerk grub, surely it must be cultural appropriation for Ms Butler to rattle up a bit of sushi?This would be the crazy conclusion to the war on cultural appropriation — none of us would ever dip into other cultures and experience their pleasures.What is most depressing about the Butler/Oliver spat is that it confirms how mainstream the miserabilist, divisive PC worldview has gone.It used to be just time-rich posh kids and snowflakes on university campuses who raged against cultural appropriation.Like the officious students at Cambridge who banned an Around The World in 80 Days fancy-dress party for fear students would wear “culturally appropriated” costumes.Or the clipboard bores at the University of East Anglia who banned students from wearing sombreros.Or the easily offended muppets at the University of Ottawa in Canada who banned a yoga class, because for white people to indulge in this ancient Indian discipline is an act of “cultural genocide”.I bet you never knew that when you do a pelvic tilt at your local gym you are being a horrible racist.Now, however, with Butler’s missive against the crimes of Jamie Oliver, this PC claptrap has crept from the fringes into the political centre. Butler is Shadow Secretary for Women and Equalities, and she is very close to Jeremy Corbyn.Is this what we should expect under a Corbyn government? Finger-wagging at anyone who deviates from PC rules?The worst thing about the clampdown on cultural appropriation is how divisive it is. The message is that we must always stick with our own cultures and never borrow from others.Didn’t that used to be known as racism?In recent years, Beyonce has been slammed for wearing a sari. Glastonbury has banned attendees from wearing Native American head-dresses. Selena Gomez was ridiculed for doing a Bollywood- inspired dance on US TV.This new racial divisiveness makes ­culture stiff and dull.Anthony Horowitz, author of the Alex Rider teen spy novels, says he was “warned off” from writing a black character. Apparently a white writer like him ­cannot understand the black experience.Is this really the world we want to live in? Where people never mix and never try to empathise with those who have had different life experiences to theirs?We should stand up for cultural ­appropriation.The global intermingling of food and fashion and art has enriched human life.As the great American novelist Lionel Shriver reminds us: “People with different backgrounds rubbing up against each other and exchanging ideas and practices is self-evidently one of the most productive, fascinating aspects of modern urban life.”Yet in their Brave New World, everyone would stick to their own people and their own ways. What a dispiriting, divided world that would be.I would far rather live in a world than has Jamie Oliver jerk chicken in it than in such a racially regimented PC nightmare.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: thirsty brits boosted public coffers by 300m during world cup and summer heatwave because they drank so much alcohol
story: The additional cash in the public purse is enough to fund 13,557 nurses pay for a year or 15,021 coppers.New figures show that thirsty footy fans and sunshine revellers put away 7.4 per cent MORE this year alcohol compared to wash out 2017.And the partying prompted the massive increase in a the tax take on beer, wine and spirit duties.Between April and the end of July the sin taxes raised £3.98billion, compared to £3.7billion in the same period last year.July alone saw an extra £52million in booze tax take.It comes as public sector borrowing data today shows the largest July surplus in 18 years.Figures from the Office for National Statistics show public sector net borrowing was in surplus by £2billion in July, £1billion more than the surplus logged in July 2017.Economists had been expecting a surplus of £1.1billion.This was the largest July surplus since the year 2000.Government coffers were bolstered by receipts on self-assessed income tax, which are usually higher in January and to a lesser extent in July - as well as the additional booze take.The Treasury said: “Thanks to the hard work of the British people, government borrowing is down.”

title: labour second referendum brexit jeremy corbyn
story: Frontbenchers are polling voters on whether they support rerunning the 2016 vote - and even staying in the EU.Brexit backers accuse the party of laying the ground for a U-turn which would see Labour endorsing a second referendum.Two shadow ministers and one parliamentary aide are all currently promoting web surveys on Brexit.Sharon Hodgson, shadow minister for public health, is asking voters if the Brexit deal should be approved in a referendum.She also asks whether theyd like to see Britain remain in the EU if we are on course to crash out without a deal.Shadow housing minister Sarah Jones asks in her survey if the final deal should be subject to a public vote.And James Frith, a parliamentary private secretary, asks: Would you prefer Parliament, the Prime Minister or you the people to have the final say on the deal negotiated by the Government?Pro-EU sources told The Sun that these surveys are often pushed in order to justify a change of policy.Leading Brexiteers accused the party of preparing to perform a U-turn and come out in support of a second referendum.Businessman John Longworth, boss of the Leave Means Leave campaign, told The Sun: “We sincerely hope that these surveys taking place are not part of a permanent shift by the Labour party to betray the democratic EU referendum and call for a second vote.”Tory MP Andrea Jenkyns added: Labour may want to waste public money on another referendum and let public trust in politicians be eroded further, but I certainly dont agree with them.And Andrew Bridgen said: It’s clear that despite their promise to the electorate to respect the referendum result, the Labour party are shifting their position to be a party of Remain.Labour Brexit supporters warned pro-EU MPs not to rock the boat by defying Jeremy Corbyns policy of accepting the 2016 referendum.Brendan Chilton, who ran Labour Leave, said: There is a concerted movement within parts of the Labour movement to try and overturn the referendum result.All members of the shadow ministerial team should support the manifesto they were elected on.Keir Starmer, the Shadow Brexit Secretary, is understood to be frustrated by the efforts to call a second referendum.He has told allies the move is a distraction from the aim of keeping Britain in the customs union - and believes those behind it are just trying to build their own profile.A Labour spokesman said: We’re not calling for a second referendum on Brexit.The MPs involved denied trying to overturn the result of the Brexit vote.Ms Jones said: “This is a survey of my constituents to hear their views - it doesn’t mean I’m advocating a second referendum”.Ms Hodgson said she only wants to ensure that I can represent my constituents in the best way possible.Mr Frith did not respond to a request for comment.Anti-Brexit campaigners welcomed the news that MPs could change their stance on a second referendum.Eloise Todd, head of Best for Britain, said: MPs are rightly asking their constituents what they think about Brexit and I hope they will hear back that it is a disaster.It is sad that Brexiteers are shrieking about an MP getting in touch with the people they represent.

title: algarve british tourist richard chapelow banana boat jon hunt foxtons
story: Authorities believe Brit Richard Chapelow, 29, may have been knocked unconscious after being thrown from the inflatable while holidaying with Foxtons boss Jon Hunts son.Billionaire Mr Hunt is a real estate magnate who built the Foxtons property empire from scratch in the early 1980s.A source at the GNR police force said: We don’t know what happened but we suspect that the banana boat the missing man was on turned over and he may have hit his head and lost consciousness and wasn’t able to swim back to the surface.“We don’t have much hope now. The search and rescue mission continues, over a wider area now than before, but it is a search mission for a body.It was also reported that Richard was staying at Mr Hunts Portugal holiday home at the time of his death.Last night the 65-year-old Foxtons founder said: My family and I are devastated by the loss of Richard, following a tragic accident at Santa Clara Dam.Our thoughts and prayers are wholly with Richard’s family, and we ask that both families are given space to grieve such a painful loss.We will be working closely with the Portuguese authorities to understand what has happened, and are grateful to the local police and fire services for their efforts. It is a time of great sorrow.”Specialist fire service divers were last night still searching for Richard after he disappeared at the dam near the city of Ourique, just over an hour’s drive north of the Algarve resort of Portimao.The alarm was raised just before 5pm local time on Monday.Initial reports said he was one of three Brits in a boat that overturned on the dam, once the largest artificial lake in the country and a popular destination for fishing enthusiasts as well as fans of water sports.Bright, fun-loving Richard from Stamford Brook, West London, had been working as a senior account manager at a London property firm after a stint as a marketing executive.Prior to that he attended the £19,000-a-year Latymer Upper School and then gained an arts degree at Leeds University.Yesterday the fire chief leading the search said they were likely looking for a body.Commander Mario Batista said: The search teams know they are probably looking for a body at this stage but it may be time before there is any news.Visibility is very poor and the water has a depth of up to 104 feet in the deepest places. In a worst case scenario it could take days to find the missing mans body.Essex-born Mr Hunt founded Foxtons in 1981 and is now worth just over £1billion - after selling the company for £375 million at the height of the property boom in May 2007.The dad-of-four is a collector of supercars including vintage Ferraris, and has two daughters called Georgie and Emma and two grown-up sons called Harry and Max.Richard’s distraught parents - solicitor father John, 67, and 66-year-old mother Jacqueline - were unavailable for comment last night.A spokesperson for the Foreign Office said: We are assisting the family of a British man reported missing in Portugal, and are in contact with the local authorities.

title: girl pictures loch ness monster scotland
story: Charlotte Robinson, 12, from Leeds was staying at the Loch Ness Highland Lodges at Invermoriston with her parents when she spotted the elusive beast just 50ft away on the first day of her holiday.Charlotte says the famous monster popped its head out of the water for about a minute before resurfacing ten feet further away around seven minutes later.The little girl was with her mum Kat, 41, a business intelligence data analyst, and dad Dave, 52, a factory worker.Nessie made her appearance last Friday, August 17 and Charlotte managed to capture the moment on her Apple phone.Charlotte told the Daily Record: There was something in the water about 50 feet from the shore. I took a photo. It had a neck and head was in the shape of a hook.I just took what I saw. It was black - I just dont know how far it was out of the water. Im not good at judging distances.But after about a minute it disappeared and then came back up again in a different place. It was up for less than a minute the second time.I kinda believed in Nessie, but I wanted to see the proof. I always imagined her as having a long neck and flippers.I have seen something but Im not sure what.Mum Kat said: “I couldnt believe it. Somethings there. With all the sightings over the years there must be something in the loch.Nessie expert Steve Feltham, 55, who has been searching for Nessie for 27 years said he was “totally excited” by the photo and thought it was the best one in years.So far this year there have been four official sightings of the monster.Earlier this month an unnamed tourist claimed to have filmed the monster poking out of the water of the loch.In May, a schoolgirl and her gran claimed to have caught The Loch Ness Monster on camera while going for a paddle in the iconic lake.Eight-year-old Laria Annand began recording after her gran Marie noticed a mysterious ripple on the water.Last year there were 11 accepted sightings, the highest number this century.The mystery surrounding the monster brings a huge tourist boost to the area, estimated to be worth £30million a year.

title: couple debate crumble custard ratio
story: It was sparked by a bloke posting a photo of his wife’s dessert – and it has divided the internet.When it comes to food we are a nation bitterly divided with strong opinions on either side for issues like milk in before or after adding the tea and whether or not Brussels sprouts are the work of the devil.But now Reddit user known as Jibbist has got the nation bitterly divided once again over the question of custard.The user posted a picture of two bowls of custard, both filled with a helping of some tasty-looking crumble but the bowls had very different amounts of custard poured over them.In a post on the thread, he said: “This was plum crumble, if any one is wondering. I’m on the right, wife in the wrong.” The debate also revealed some interesting alternatives to what some people poured over custard instead of the traditional pudding of crumble.Jonny Segment wrote: “The left side is the right amount. The right side looks like an accidental spillage of custard that you might expect in any given meal, on average.”While WufflyTime thought neither were correct, writing: “Left sides too much. Right sides not enough.”But Samhastings, who clearly loves custard, said: “Right sides not enough, left sides not enough. MORE CUSTARD.”Another users Yawning_iscontagious tended to agree with Samhastings, saying: “What is the point if it’s not literally smothered in it?”Deep61 also thought more custard was best, writing: “The one on the left with just a little more custard methinks.”But not only did it spark a debate on the amount of custard required but also what foods went well with custard.Rallybugs, wanted to relive their youth and mix in hundreds and thousands.They wrote: “Custard, on its own.“To relive my youth, mix in hundreds and thousands or chocolate strands until the custard melts them and changes colour...“Also, hot custard on cold treacle tart is the business!”Although Throwaway622796 thought digestives went well with custard.But another, Deep61, preferred jaffa cakes while Whendrinksmix suggested Maltesers and marshmallows.If that wasn’t enough, Lost and Not Found threw a spanner in the works by rejecting custard completely and preferring cream.But that’s a whole other can of worms…

title: spot snake hiding picture viral
story: The serpent was removed from a home in Ninderry, Queensland by Sunshine Coast Snake Catchers 24/7 on Monday.Facebook was awash with confused snake spotters left struggling to locate the reptile.The photo shows two brown stools pushed close together with a few magazines lying on top.Melissa Neunendorf joked: “The newest edition of Wheres Wally I can never find the snake.”Diana Randolph Cain added: “I’m doomed, doomed I tell you! In a picture of two chairs I do not see a snake.Facebook4 Facebook4“It’s called spot the snake so I can’t say it’s teeny tiny hiding under the papers.“So unless it’s camouflaged itself to look like a magazine I see nothing, nothing at all…for the love.”The post also added there would be extra points for users who can guess the species.So, can YOU spot it?The tiny snake had curled itself around the leg of the right-hand stool.Some eagle-eyed users even went as far as to guess the species.One said: “Too hard to get a look to figure out the species, but gotta be a scrub python at that size right???”Lockie Gilding, who attended the call in Ninderry, identified the reptile as a brown tree snake, Yahoo7 reports.Gilding also recognised it as a hatchling less than a year old.Although slightly venomous, such snakes are not considered to be dangerous.Despite its tiny size, one user commented “even though its small Id leave it well alone - some of those small snakes are as toxic as those bigger ones”.

title: former boss of britains biggest speed camera company has got a second driving ban for using mobile phone
story: Tom Riall, 58, was head of Serco Government Division, which oversaw 5,000 Gatsos.He got a six-month ban and £2,500 fine by Reading JPs for the offence near Langley, Berks.In May 2009 he got a six month ban for doing 103mph in a 70mph limit on the A14 in Newmarket, Suffolk.Investigating officer, PC Jessica Barker, of the Thames Valley Police’s Roads Policing unit said: “We take the offence of using a mobile phone whilst driving very seriously.“Drivers distracted by using a mobile phone have a higher chance of being involved in a serious or fatal collision.”A Thames Valley Police spokesman said: Due to it being a high fine, we want to set an example and show people why they shouldn’t be on their phone whilst driving.”Speaking from his six-bed home in Ufton Nervet, Berks, Mr Riall – now chief executive of Integrated Dental Holdings Group Limited, said: “No comment.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
